body:
Thank you for your pull request. Before we can look at your contribution, we need to ensure all contributors are covered by a Contributor License Agreement.

After the following items are addressed, please respond with a new comment here, and the automated system will re-verify.

* User @santoshankr isn't covered by a CLA. They will need to complete the form at https://identity.linuxfoundation.org/projects/cncf

_Regards,
CLA GitHub bot_

Thank you for your pull request. Before we can look at your contribution, we need to ensure all contributors are covered by a Contributor License Agreement.

After the following items are addressed, please respond with a new comment here, and the automated system will re-verify.

* User @santoshankr isn't covered by a CLA. They will need to complete the form at https://identity.linuxfoundation.org/projects/cncf

_Regards,
CLA GitHub bot_
CLA signed!
@jiangtaoli2016 @nathanielmanistaatgoogle hi, can you review the change please?
Does the latest change address your questions @nathanielmanistaatgoogle ?
@nathanielmanistaatgoogle gentle ping
@jiangtaoli2016 Hi, can someone review the change please? It have been two weeks since last activity...

> Why should this be an object in the API of gRPC Python as opposed to just an integer-valued channel argument?

This option was defined in #14483. Allowing a pointer argument buys us more flexibility - callers can implement their own caching policy, and multiple clients can share a session cache so only one of them needs to take a hit from TLS handshake overhead. 

This changeset simply provides callers with a standard implementation that can be passed as a value for the existing `grpc.ssl_session_cache` option. There is no requirement to use this implementation. This is conceptually similar to the way `ClientSessionCahe` works in Go's `crypto/tls`. (The user is free to use their own type that implements the `ClientSessionCache` interface, but the library provides a standard one via`NewLRUClientSessionCache` for convenience)

> This option was defined in #14483. Allowing a pointer argument buys us more flexibility - callers can implement their own caching policy,

How? The API change introduces a concrete class with no exposed methods. Does Python's affinity for duck typing mean that I can then pass any object (like `None`, or `3`, or `object()`) as a valid substitute for an instance of `grpc.SSLSessionCache`? Notice that all the other concrete classes in the gRPC Python API are warts that we regret (the doc strings "This class has no supported interface - it exists to define the type of its instances and its instances exist to be passed to other functions." are downright _embarrassing_) and that we'd like to avoid adding any more non-data-only non-behaviorless classes to the API. Notice that `grpc.Channel` is an interface that anyone can implement. Should `grpc.SSLSessionCache` also be an interface? If so, what should the methods on it be?

> and multiple clients can share a session cache so only one of them needs to take a hit from TLS handshake overhead.

I thought something like this might be intended to be the case, but the unit test included in this pull request does not exercise this capability, so it wouldn't be properly supported as a critical user journey.

> How? The API change introduces a concrete class with no exposed methods.

It's free room for future extensions. Once needed grpc-core can expose function like `grpc_ssl_session_cache_create_custom(*vtable)` and we would be able to allow users to create their own implementations of `grpc.SSLSessionCache`.

> I thought something like this might be intended to be the case, but the unit test included in this pull request does not exercise this capability, so it wouldn't be properly supported as a critical user journey.

This functionality is currently tested as part of grpc-core, we can replicate tests here of course, but I've thought that python tests are mostly to ensure that binding is wired up through correctly, not that grpc-core internally works as expected?

> I thought something like this might be intended to be the case, but the unit test included in this pull request does not exercise this capability

I don't see why this is true. Every `_do_one_shot_client_rpc` call in the test creates a new channel that shares the cache we created.
@jiangtaoli2016 @nathanielmanistaatgoogle hi, gentle ping after 8 days of radio silence.
SSL session cache has indeed been extensively tested on grpc-core. Thanks @euroelessar for contribution.
Hi @jiangtaoli2016 @nathanielmanistaatgoogle. Is there anything else that needs discussion here?
@nathanielmanistaatgoogle Could you please review this PR?

> Would you be willing to move the new application-facing code elements to grpc.experimental.ssl_session_cache?

Sure. For now, the only behavior expected of an `SSLSessionCache` implementation is that it declare an `__int__` method that returns a pointer to a `grpc_ssl_session_cache` type. There's no good way for callers to create one (yet), so making this an interface doesn't seem meaningful.

The `testSSLSessionCacheLRU` test seems to be triggering a segfault after the rebase above. I'm able to reproduce the failure reliably with these steps:

1. Start a secure server
2. Start a secure client with `grpc.ssl_session_cache_lru` set. The client is told to make an RPC call, print a success message, then sleep for 10s before exiting
3. After the RPC succeeds, stop the server. In a few seconds, the client crashes with `Segmentation fault (core dumped)`

Here's a stack trace:
```
#0  copy_arg (src=src@entry=0x7fffec017b20) at src/core/lib/channel/channel_args.cc:50
#1  0x00007ffff6889e43 in grpc_channel_args_copy_and_add_and_remove (src=0x7fffec017a20,
    to_remove=0x0, num_to_remove=0, to_add=0x0, num_to_add=0)
    at src/core/lib/channel/channel_args.cc:106
#2  0x00007ffff690ca72 in create_key (args=0x7fffec017a00,
    copy_channel_args=0x7ffff6889f00 <grpc_channel_args_copy(grpc_channel_args const*)>)
    at src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/subchannel_index.cc:61
#3  0x00007ffff68895e5 in remove_key (vtable=0x7ffff6cc3700 <subchannel_avl_vtable>,
    node=0x7fffec016a40, key=key@entry=0x7fffec001bc0, user_data=user_data@entry=0x7ffff3df0e80)
    at src/core/lib/avl/avl.cc:282
#4  0x00007ffff6889888 in grpc_avl_remove (avl=..., key=key@entry=0x7fffec001bc0,
    user_data=user_data@entry=0x7ffff3df0e80) at src/core/lib/avl/avl.cc:291
#5  0x00007ffff690cf7d in grpc_subchannel_index_unregister (key=0x7fffec001bc0,
    constructed=constructed@entry=0x7fffec017500)
    at src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/subchannel_index.cc:238
#6  0x00007ffff690b943 in disconnect (c=0x7fffec017500)
    at src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/subchannel.cc:234
#7  grpc_subchannel_unref (c=0x7fffec017500)
    at src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/subchannel.cc:251
#8  0x00007ffff691db08 in grpc_core::SubchannelData<grpc_core::(anonymous namespace)::PickFirst::PickFirstSubchannelList, grpc_core::(anonymous namespace)::PickFirst::PickFirstSubchannelData>::UnrefSubchannelLocked (this=this@entry=0x7fffec011f20,
    reason=reason@entry=0x7ffff6a26d07 "pf_selected_shutdown")
    #9  0x00007ffff691f077 in grpc_core::(anonymous namespace)::PickFirst::PickFirstSubchannelData::ProcessConnectivityChangeLocked (this=0x7fffec011f20, connectivity_state=GRPC_CHANNEL_TRANSIENT_FAILURE,
    error=0x7fffe4000da0)
    at src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/lb_policy/pick_first/pick_first.cc:439
#10 0x00007ffff6892aa2 in grpc_combiner_continue_exec_ctx () at src/core/lib/iomgr/combiner.cc:260
#11 0x00007ffff689f86d in grpc_core::ExecCtx::Flush (this=0x7ffff3df0e80)
    at src/core/lib/iomgr/exec_ctx.cc:131
#12 0x00007ffff6895f2e in end_worker (worker_hdl=0x2, worker=0x7ffff3df0970, pollset=0xd2b9c0)
    at src/core/lib/iomgr/ev_epoll1_linux.cc:880
#13 pollset_work (ps=0xd2b9c0, worker_hdl=<optimized out>, deadline=<optimized out>)
    at src/core/lib/iomgr/ev_epoll1_linux.cc:980
#14 0x00007ffff68feacd in run_poller (arg=0xd31060, error=<optimized out>)
    at src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/backup_poller.cc:122
#15 0x00007ffff689f849 in exec_ctx_run (error=0x0, closure=<optimized out>)
    at src/core/lib/iomgr/exec_ctx.cc:40
#16 grpc_core::ExecCtx::Flush (this=0x7ffff3df0e80) at src/core/lib/iomgr/exec_ctx.cc:128
#17 0x00007ffff68aeb59 in run_some_timers () at src/core/lib/iomgr/timer_manager.cc:121
#18 timer_main_loop () at src/core/lib/iomgr/timer_manager.cc:222
#19 timer_thread (completed_thread_ptr=0xd73ae0) at src/core/lib/iomgr/timer_manager.cc:269
#20 0x00007ffff68886dc in grpc_core::(anonymous namespace)::ThreadInternalsPosix::ThreadInternalsPosix(char const*, void (*)(void*), void*, bool*)::{lambda(void*)#1}::_FUN(void*) ()
    at src/core/lib/gprpp/thd_posix.cc:100
---Type <return> to continue, or q <return> to quit---
#21 0x00007ffff7bc16ba in start_thread (arg=0x7ffff3df1700) at pthread_create.c:333
#22 0x00007ffff78f741d in clone () at ../sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/x86_64/clone.S:109
```

[`copy_arg`](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/src/core/lib/channel/channel_args.cc#L48) crashes when it tries to copy the `grpc.ssl_session_cache` channel option after the server exits. I suspect that the [vtable](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/channel.pyx.pxi#L395) `grpc.Channel` uses for all pointer-valued args is somehow getting cleaned up, so `vtable->copy` is pointing at garbage.

`git bisect` suggests this first appeared after https://github.com/grpc/grpc/commit/ca7ba4d, but I don't yet understand gRPC internals (or Cython) well enough to determine how that's causing the behavior above. I'll continue digging. 

Is there a reason all pointer arguments use the same vtable? Would it be reasonable, for example, to check if `value` has a `vtable` function at https://github.com/grpc/grpc/tree/master/src/python/grpcio/grpc/_cython/_cygrpc/arguments.pyx.pxi#L58 and use the return value from that instead?
@santoshankr: I think I see the issue and am working toward a fix. Next few hours? :crossed_fingers:
I think there's a gRPC Core issue blocking this and I'm going to talk to some folks today about it. Sorry for the additional delay!

Just an update: I'm working on the channel-side pointer-valued channel args issue that is blocking this, but having trouble making the fix I want to make. I'll put in a workaround if it doesn't get resolved in the next few days.

I very much want this change in `1.13` and I suspect y'all do as well?
Getting this into 1.13 would be great. Is there anything I can help with?
I think the changes in [pull request 15666](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/15666) should unblock this; if you have time please test out and confirm?
Squashed commits, added a commit message and called `.close()` on the channel created in `_do_one_shot_client_rpc`
Commit message looks a little wide? [Does it fit within seventy-two columns?](https://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/#seven-rules)
Make commit message 72 chars wide
Sorry for the nitpicking (though it means we're nearly done!) but make a second proofreading of your commit message? It looks like there's a parenthetical that opens but never closes; is that right?
Heh, git swallowed the line starting with "#14483) ..." because it treated that as a comment.
